articles.headline: How to Prepare When Next Year’s Tax Rates Are Anyone’s Guess
articles.snippet: The fiscal stalemate in Washington has left many with no idea how much they’ll be paying in federal income taxes in 2013, but taxpayers can take some  steps amid the uncertainty.
articles.abstract: The fiscal stalemate in Washington has left many with no idea how much they’ll be paying in federal income taxes in 2013, but taxpayers can take some  steps amid the uncertainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: This was the week we were supposed to get a grand bargain. Instead, we got an undignified stalemate.

articles.headline: Partial Deal With Union Averts a Strike at 14 Ports
articles.snippet: Shipping companies and dockworkers reached a deal on their main dispute, and the longshoremen’s union agreed to drop its threat of a strike this Sunday.
articles.abstract: Shipping companies and dockworkers reached a deal on their main dispute, and the longshoremen’s union agreed to drop its threat of a strike this Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dockworkers dropped their threat of an imminent strike against ports from Boston to Houston after their union and shipping companies reached a deal on the main point of their dispute, a federal mediator announced on Friday.

articles.headline: Senate Leaders Set to Work on a Last-Minute Tax Agreement
articles.snippet: After weeks of fruitless negotiations with the House speaker, John A. Boehner, President Obama turned to Senator Harry Reid and Senator Mitch McConnell to try to avert a fiscal crisis.
articles.abstract: After weeks of fruitless negotiations with the House speaker, John A. Boehner, President Obama turned to Senator Harry Reid and Senator Mitch McConnell to try to avert a fiscal crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the urging of President Obama, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate set to work Friday night to assemble a last-minute tax deal that could pass both chambers of Congress and avert large tax increases and budget cuts next year, or at least stop the worst of the economic punch from landing beginning Jan. 1.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Hurricane Sandy Alters Utilities’ Calculus on Upgrades
articles.snippet: It is typically much cheaper for a utility, and its customers, to skip prevention measures and just clean up the mess after a catastrophe, but Hurricane Sandy has changed that thinking.
articles.abstract: It is typically much cheaper for a utility, and its customers, to skip prevention measures and just clean up the mess after a catastrophe, but Hurricane Sandy has changed that thinking.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Sandy wreaked havoc with power systems in the Northeast, many consumers and public officials complained that the electric utilities had done far too little to protect their equipment from violent storms, which forecasters have warned could strike with increasing frequency.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell, Matthew L. Wald and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Revival of Hitachi the Company Is a Detriment to Hitachi the City
articles.snippet: After a staggering loss in 2009, the Hitachi Corporation has engineered a stunning turnaround, costing jobs and opportunity in its home city of Hitachi, Japan.
articles.abstract: After a staggering loss in 2009, the Hitachi Corporation has engineered a stunning turnaround, costing jobs and opportunity in its home city of Hitachi, Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: HITACHI, Japan — The biggest annual loss on record by a Japanese manufacturer jolted executives into action at the Hitachi Corporation, the century-old electronics and engineering behemoth that takes its name from this wind-swept industrial city on the Pacific Coast.

articles.headline: As Walmart Makes Safety Vows, It’s Seen as Obstacle to Change
articles.snippet: After a deadly factory fire in Bangladesh stirred soul-searching around the apparel industry, critics say Walmart has not done enough to improve safety standards.
articles.abstract: After a deadly factory fire in Bangladesh stirred soul-searching around the apparel industry, critics say Walmart has not done enough to improve safety standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Walmart’s chief executive, Michael Duke, appeared at a Council on Foreign Relations meeting in New York this month, a raucous crowd of protesters awaited him. Walmart was confronting reports of bribery in Mexico, a wave of labor demonstrations in the United States and, perhaps most critically, questions about a grisly fire that had killed 112 workers at a Bangladeshi garment factory used by several Walmart suppliers.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: Senate Seeks Bipartisan Formula to Reach Tax Deal
articles.snippet: The fear of another painful economic slowdown appears to have accelerated deal-making on Capitol Hill with just two days remaining before the so-called fiscal cliff arrives.
articles.abstract: The fear of another painful economic slowdown appears to have accelerated deal-making on Capitol Hill with just two days remaining before the so-called fiscal cliff arrives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders and their aides spent Saturday searching for a formula to extend tax cuts for most Americans that could win bipartisan support in the Senate and final approval in the fractious House by the new year, hoping to prevent large tax increases and budget cuts that could threaten the fragile economy.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: An Idea Promised the Sky, but India Is Still Waiting
articles.snippet: The Aakash project was supposed to provide $50 tablet computers for students across India, revolutionizing the nation’s schools and its tech industry, but so far those goals remain elusive.
articles.abstract: The Aakash project was supposed to provide $50 tablet computers for students across India, revolutionizing the nation’s schools and its tech industry, but so far those goals remain elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The idea was, and still is, captivating: in 2011, the Indian government and two Indian-born tech entrepreneurs unveiled a $50 tablet computer, to be built in India with Google’s free Android software. The government would buy the computers by the millions and give them to its schoolchildren.
articles.byline: By Pamposh Raina, Ian Austen and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Questcor Finds Profits, at $28,000 a Vial
articles.snippet: After pricing its once-obscure drug, Acthar, in the stratosphere, Questcor gained many fans on Wall Street. But the company has also drawn some doubters.
articles.abstract: After pricing its once-obscure drug, Acthar, in the stratosphere, Questcor gained many fans on Wall Street. But the company has also drawn some doubters.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif.

articles.headline: Biden Is Back for a 2nd Run at Gun Limits
articles.snippet: The current debate offers Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. a chance to craft a legislative response that would reinstate his assault weapons ban, while also making it more effective.
articles.abstract: The current debate offers Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. a chance to craft a legislative response that would reinstate his assault weapons ban, while also making it more effective.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Never much known for restraint, Joseph R. Biden Jr. did not hold back during a presidential primary debate in 2007 when a voter asking about gun rights in a recorded video displayed a fearsome-looking semiautomatic rifle and declared, “This is my baby.”

articles.headline: Drone War Spurs Militants to Deadly Reprisals
articles.snippet: Militants in Pakistan’s tribal belt tape confessions and executions of men accused of aiding drone attacks, deepening an atmosphere of paranoia and mistrust.
articles.abstract: Militants in Pakistan’s tribal belt tape confessions and executions of men accused of aiding drone attacks, deepening an atmosphere of paranoia and mistrust.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — They are dead men talking, and they know it. Gulping nervously, the prisoners stare into the video camera, spilling tales of intrigue, betrayal and paid espionage on behalf of the United States. Some speak in trembling voices, a glint of fear in their eyes. Others look resigned. All plead for their lives.

articles.headline: Coming Soon to Belgian Village, a French Film Idol Fleeing Taxes
articles.snippet: Néchin, a rural settlement in Belgium, has become a tax haven for scores of wealthy French citizens, including, most recently, the actor Gérard Depardieu.
articles.abstract: Néchin, a rural settlement in Belgium, has become a tax haven for scores of wealthy French citizens, including, most recently, the actor Gérard Depardieu.
articles.lead_paragraph: NÉCHIN, Belgium — The last time a big star lit up this sleepy village of potato fields and rain-drenched pastures was in 1667, when the Sun King, Louis XIV of France, stopped by for the day. But even he may not have created quite the commotion caused by Gérard Depardieu, the celebrated actor, turbulent bon vivant and, since a visit to the mayor’s office here on Dec. 7 to register as a resident, France’s most reviled tax exile.

articles.headline: Day of Seesaw Talks Produces No Accord on Fiscal Crisis
articles.snippet: The Senate was set to reconvene Monday after failing to produce a fiscal deal with just hours to go before large tax increases and spending cuts were to begin taking effect.
articles.abstract: The Senate was set to reconvene Monday after failing to produce a fiscal deal with just hours to go before large tax increases and spending cuts were to begin taking effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders on Sunday failed to produce a fiscal deal with just hours to go before large tax increases and spending cuts were to begin taking effect on New Year’s Day, despite a round of volatile negotiations over the weekend and an attempt by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to intervene.

articles.headline: Big Depositors Seek a New Safety Net
articles.snippet: With $1.5 trillion of bank deposits losing an unlimited government guarantee granted in the financial crisis, services are parceling cash into F.D.I.C.-insurable bundles at multiple banks.
articles.abstract: With $1.5 trillion of bank deposits losing an unlimited government guarantee granted in the financial crisis, services are parceling cash into F.D.I.C.-insurable bundles at multiple banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the first day of the New Year, $1.5 trillion of bank deposits will lose an unlimited government guarantee that was granted during the financial crisis to assure skittish customers that their cash was safe. For a handful of boutique firms that service banks, it’s a boon for business.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Maxim Recruits a Readership in Uniform
articles.snippet: Maxim, a magazine featuring adolescent humor and plenty of scantily clad actresses, has courted the armed forces, veterans and their families as a source of growing readership.
articles.abstract: Maxim, a magazine featuring adolescent humor and plenty of scantily clad actresses, has courted the armed forces, veterans and their families as a source of growing readership.
articles.lead_paragraph: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ark. — Scaling elevator shafts and sliding through sewers in mud-caked fields at a military training camp here would not be what most people would call a vacation. But for 10 Special Operations soldiers from the Army, Navy, Marines and Air Force, participating in an event called the Maximum Warrior contest, these challenges had a singular aim: to be in Maxim magazine.

articles.headline: U.S. Clears DNA Firm’s Acquisition by Chinese
articles.snippet: The controversial purchase of a Silicon Valley-based DNA sequencing company by a Chinese firm has raised concerns about American competitiveness in a field that is becoming a big business.
articles.abstract: The controversial purchase of a Silicon Valley-based DNA sequencing company by a Chinese firm has raised concerns about American competitiveness in a field that is becoming a big business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government has given national security clearance to the controversial purchase of an American DNA sequencing company by a Chinese firm.

articles.headline: Family of Chinese Regulator Profits in Insurance Firm’s Rise
articles.snippet: Dai Xianglong oversaw the insurance industry when a company his relatives helped control made an investment that came to be worth billions.
articles.abstract: Dai Xianglong oversaw the insurance industry when a company his relatives helped control made an investment that came to be worth billions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Relatives of a top Chinese regulator profited enormously from the purchase of shares in a once-struggling insurance company that is now one of China’s biggest financial powerhouses, according to interviews and a review of regulatory filings.

articles.headline: Engineering a Reversal of Fortune in 2013
articles.snippet: Given the number of changes in the media industry, the coming year is particularly important for a group of leaders who confront steep challenges ahead.
articles.abstract: Given the number of changes in the media industry, the coming year is particularly important for a group of leaders who confront steep challenges ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: In business, all years are critical — make a big mistake and you won’t have the chance to make another one. But in the media, wave after wave of transformation mean the coming year is particularly important.

articles.headline: Settlement Expected on Past Abuses in Home Loans
articles.snippet: Banking regulators are said to be close to a $10 billion settlement with 14 banks that would end the government’s efforts to hold lenders responsible for foreclosure abuses.
articles.abstract: Banking regulators are said to be close to a $10 billion settlement with 14 banks that would end the government’s efforts to hold lenders responsible for foreclosure abuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banking regulators are close to a $10 billion settlement with 14 banks that would end the government’s efforts to hold lenders responsible for foreclosure abuses like faulty paperwork and excessive fees that may have led to evictions, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.

articles.headline: Experts Forecast the Cost of Failure to Compromise
articles.snippet: Observers say that the budget impasse in Washington will place a drag upon the American economy in the first half of 2013 whether a last-minute deal can be hammered out or not.
articles.abstract: Observers say that the budget impasse in Washington will place a drag upon the American economy in the first half of 2013 whether a last-minute deal can be hammered out or not.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even if President Obama and Republicans in Congress can reach a last-minute compromise that averts some tax increases before Monday’s midnight deadline, experts still foresee a significant drag on the economy in the first half of 2013 from the fiscal impasse in Washington.

articles.headline: Indian Women March: ‘That Girl Could Have Been Any One of Us’
articles.snippet: Protesters say they and others like them will never fully take part in the promise of a more prosperous nation unless something fundamental changes.
articles.abstract: Protesters say they and others like them will never fully take part in the promise of a more prosperous nation unless something fundamental changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Neha Kaul Mehra says she was only 7 years old the first time she was sexually harassed. She was walking to a dance class in an affluent neighborhood of New Delhi when a man confronted her and began openly masturbating.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Sruthi Gottipati

articles.headline: Thomas the Tank Engine to Receive a Multimillion-Dollar Sheen
articles.snippet: Mattel, which owns the gentle, chubby-cheeked British train and his friends, will be taking steps to ramp up the brand’s presence internationally, trying to retain the sweetness of the characters.
articles.abstract: Mattel, which owns the gentle, chubby-cheeked British train and his friends, will be taking steps to ramp up the brand’s presence internationally, trying to retain the sweetness of the characters.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of the oldest preschool entertainment and toy franchises, Thomas the Tank Engine, is about to get a new marketing push.

articles.headline: A Showdown Long Foreseen
articles.snippet: The struggle over how to reach a broad Congressional tax agreement is not just the latest partisan showdown but rather the culmination of two years of escalating fiscal confrontations.
articles.abstract: The struggle over how to reach a broad Congressional tax agreement is not just the latest partisan showdown but rather the culmination of two years of escalating fiscal confrontations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The titanic struggle over how to reach a broad Congressional tax agreement is not just the latest partisan showdown, but rather the culmination of two years of escalating fiscal confrontations, each building on the other in its gravity and consequences. On Sunday, lawmakers could not seem to find one final way out.

articles.headline: Tribune, Bankruptcy Over, Is Expected to Sell Assets
articles.snippet: Analysts and prospective buyers are preparing for horse trading to begin over the company’s newspapers.
articles.abstract: Analysts and prospective buyers are preparing for horse trading to begin over the company’s newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: 6:12 p.m. | Updated

articles.headline: Tentative Deal Is Reached to Raise Taxes on the Wealthy
articles.snippet: The Senate moved toward a vote to allow taxes to rise on the affluent and put off cuts in spending, but the House would not consider any deal until Tuesday, meaning Congress missed its deadline on the so-called fiscal cliff.
articles.abstract: The Senate moved toward a vote to allow taxes to rise on the affluent and put off cuts in spending, but the House would not consider any deal until Tuesday, meaning Congress missed its deadline on the so-called fiscal cliff.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Furious last-minute negotiations between the White House and the Senate Republican leadership on Monday secured a tentative agreement to allow tax rates to rise on affluent Americans, but not in time for Congress to meet its Dec. 31 deadline for averting automatic tax increases and spending cuts deemed a threat to the economy.

articles.headline: Shares End Higher on Hope for Fiscal Deal
articles.snippet: Stocks surged after reports emerged that an agreement might be near in Washington.
articles.abstract: Stocks surged after reports emerged that an agreement might be near in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks were driven sharply higher on the last day of the year by signs that a resolution to the fiscal negotiations in Washington could come within days.
